'''Willie Clayton''' (born March 29, 1955) is an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] and [[soul-blues]] singer and songwriter. He has recorded over 25 [[album]]s since the 1980s.<ref name="AMG"/> Performing since the late 1960s,<ref name="AMG"/> from the 1980s onwards his [[record chart|chart]] successes span the decades.<ref name="Awards">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/willie-clayton-mn0000686522/awards |title=Willie Clayton - Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=1955-03-29 |accessdate=2013-03-28}}</ref>

[[Allmusic]] noted that Clayton is "one of those vocalists who could sing the phone book and the result would sound perfectly phrased and memorable."<ref>{{cite web|last=Leggett |first=Steve |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/soul-and-blues-mw0000801455 |title=Soul and Blues - Willie Clayton : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2008-11-04 |accessdate=2013-03-28}}</ref> Along with [[Buddy Guy]], [[Koko Taylor]], and [[Little Milton]], Clayton was one of the most important figures in Chicago blues in the 1970s and 1980s.<ref>{{cite book
| first= Emmett George
| last= Price
| year= 2011
| title= Encyclopedia of African American Music, Volume 3
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[Greenwood Publishing Group]] 
| location= [[Santa Barbara, California]] 
| isbn= 978-0-313-34199-1
| page= 197}}</ref> 

==Biography==
Clayton was born in [[Indianola, Mississippi]], United States, as one of 11 siblings.<ref name="AMG"/> He sang [[Gospel music|gospel]] in his local church as a youngster.<ref name="Willie">{{cite web|url=http://www.willieclayton.com/biography/ |title=Biography |publisher=Willie Clayton |date=2013-01-18 |accessdate=2013-03-28}}</ref> Duplex Records issued his debut [[Single (music)|single]], "That's the Way Daddy Did" (1969). In 1971, Clayton relocated to [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], and appeared regularly in the local [[nightclub|clubs]].  He was introduced to [[Al Green]]'s record producer, [[Willie Mitchell (musician)|Willie Mitchell]], who signed Clayton to a [[recording contract]] with Pawn, a subsidiary [[record label|label]] of [[Hi Records]].  Mitchell produced several tracks with Clayton, including "I Must Be Losin' You," "It's Time You Made Up Your Mind," and "Baby You're Ready," but none of them reached the national charts.  Clayton toured nationally on the same bill as Green, [[James Brown]] and [[Barry White]], before creating his own label, Sky Hero, which issued "Living with You, But My Heart Is Somewhere Else."<ref name="AMG"/>

Clayton then joined Compleat Records.  They issued a couple of singles before "Tell Me", produced by [[General Crook (musician)|General Crook]], was a modest hit in 1984.  It was followed into the [[United States|US]] ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] [[record chart|chart]] by "What A Way To Put It."<ref name="whitburnr&b"/> He returned to the R&B chart in 1989, credited by [[Polydor Records]] as '''Will Clayton''', with "Never Too Late" and "Tell Me" (a different song to his earlier hit), followed by "I Wanna Be Where You Are", on which he was co-credited with Audrey Wheeler.<ref name="whitburnr&b"/> She was a former runner-up in the [[Miss Black Universe]] contest, who also recorded with [[Jeff Lorber]] and [[Omar Chandler]], and worked as a session singer.<ref>Whitburn, 1996, p.476</ref>  Clayton also recorded a number of albums with [[Ichiban Records]].<ref name="Soul"/>  In 1992, a joint [[compilation album]] with [[Bobby McClure]], ''Bobby McClure & Willie Clayton'', was released by Hi Records.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/bobby-mcclure-willie-clayton-mw0000616862/releases |title=Bobby McClure & Willie Clayton - Bobby McClure : Releases |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-03-27}}</ref>

In 1993, [[Ace Records (United States)|Ace Records]] released the album, ''Let's Get Together'', followed by ''Simply Beautiful'' and ''It's About Love'' (1999).  His 1998 album, ''Something To Talk About'', reached number 14 on the ''Billboard'' Top Blues Albums Chart, where Clayton enjoyed similar successes for the following ten years.<ref name="AMG"/> ''Something To Talk About'' included Clayton's [[Duet (music)|duet]] with [[Tyrone Davis]] on the song, "Mine All Mine,"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/song/mine-all-mine-mt0010419393 |title=Mine All Mine - Willie Clayton, Tyrone Davis : Listen, Appearances, Song Review |publisher=AllMusic |date=1998-06-02 |accessdate=2013-03-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title= |journal=[[Jet (magazine)|Jet]] |volume=February 28, 2005 |issue= |page=p.57 |publisher=A. Johnson|doi= |url= |accessdate=2013-03-27}}</ref> along with his [[cover version]]s of the songs "[[Something to Talk About (Bonnie Raitt song)|Something to Talk About]]," and "[[Ain't No Love in the Heart of the City|Heart of the City]]."<ref>{{cite web|last=Hamilton |first=Andrew |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/something-to-talk-about-mw0000609370 |title=Something to Talk About - Willie Clayton : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=1998-06-02 |accessdate=2013-03-26}}</ref> Clayton started his own record label, EndZone in the late 1990s, before signing in 2005 to [[Malaco Records]].<ref name="Soul">{{cite web|url=http://www.soulbluesmusic.com/willieclayton.htm |title=Willie Clayton |publisher=Soulbluesmusic.com |date=1955-03-29 |accessdate=2013-03-28}}</ref>

Clayton recorded his version of "[[I Can't Stand the Rain (song)|I Can't Stand the Rain]]," on his 2008 album ''Soul & Blues''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Leggett |first=Steve |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/soul-and-blues-mw0000801455 |title=Soul and Blues - Willie Clayton : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2008-11-04 |accessdate=2012-08-08}}</ref> ''My Tyme'', which was released the same year, was his third album in a five year period to peak at number 83 on the ''Billboard'' [[Top  R&B/Hip-Hop Albums|Top R&B Albums]] Chart.<ref name="Awards"/> He returned to the singles chart in 2010, after an absence of over 20 years, with his duet recording with [[Dave Hollister]], "We Both Grown."<ref name="Soul"/>

His latest album, ''I Am Rhythm & Blues'', was released in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/i-am-rhythm-blues-mw0002431430/releases |title=I Am Rhythm & Blues - Willie Clayton : Releases |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-03-28}}</ref> In May 2013, Clayton performed at the Leflore County Civic Center in [[Greenwood, Mississippi]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.songkick.com/artists/511987-willie-clayton |title=Willie Clayton Tour Dates 2013 — Willie Clayton Concert Dates and Tickets |publisher=Songkick |date= |accessdate=2013-03-28}}</ref>
